prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded. 
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago. [info] Condemned Prisoner 
 ***** (Redacted for confidentiality) 
 Pseudonym: The Professor 
 Ddeath by hanging confirmed at midnight, 17th June. 
 Courtney Stevens. 
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion. [caption] There is blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen. 
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The special exhibit in the House of Horrors is based on a rumour that shocked society in London.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 1
Testimony: An impression of the visage was taken directly from the corpse...in accordance with Tusspells family principles.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 2
Testimony: I enlisted the aid of the gravedigger, and created a mould for the head in the cemetery just before the interment.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 3
Testimony: I hid myself until he gave me a signal. ...I was there for a very long time that night.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 4
Testimony: It took me a very long time because it was before the onset of rigor mortis.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 5
Testimony: As dawn approached, I was very worried that I could be discovered.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 6
Testimony: I hurried to finish my work in the half hour before sunrise. Then I left as soon as the corpse was interred.
Person: Tusspells

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. Let me go through them step by step.

First, let me look at the testimonies. All the testimonies are from Tusspells (Character 10). The testimonies are about creating a waxwork of the Professor. Testimony 2 says she enlisted a gravedigger and made a mold in the cemetery just before interment. Testimony 3 mentions hiding until a signal, waiting a long time. Testimony 4 says it took a long time because it was before rigor mortis. Testimony 6 states she left as soon as the corpse was interred.

Now, looking at the evidences. Evidence 15 is the Waxwork Head, which is the head of the Professor waxwork stolen from the exhibit. Evidence 16 is the Killer's Autopsy Report, which mentions the Professor's death by hanging confirmed at midnight on the 17th. Also, Evidence 19 is a ten-year-old article about the resurrection rumor.

Wait, the key contradiction might be between Tusspells' testimony and the autopsy report. She claims she made the mold before interment, but the autopsy report (Evidence 16) states the Professor was executed by hanging and death was confirmed. If the body was interred, but Tusspells made the mold from the corpse before rigor mortis (Testimony 4), but the execution was at midnight. Let me check the timeline.

Testimony 6 says she left as soon as the corpse was interred. If the execution was at midnight, and she had to wait until the body was buried, but rigor mortis usually sets in a few hours after death. If she made the mold before rigor mortis, that would mean she was working on the body shortly after death. However, the autopsy report says death was confirmed at midnight. If Tusspells was making the mold before the interment, which would be shortly after death, but the article (Evidence 19) talks about a resurrection rumor. Maybe the contradiction is that the autopsy report says the Professor was confirmed dead, but Tusspells' testimony implies she took the mold from the actual corpse, which should have been properly buried. However, the waxwork's head (Evidence 15) is part of the exhibit based on the rumor. Wait, the contradiction might be between Tusspells' testimony about making the mold from the actual corpse (Testimony 2) and the Killer's Autopsy Report (Evidence 16) which states the death was confirmed. If she took the impression from the corpse, but the autopsy report says the death was confirmed, implying the body was properly handled. However, the article (Evidence 19) talks about a resurrection, so perhaps the body wasn't actually buried, or there was a substitution. But how does that relate to a testimony?

Wait, Testimony 2 says she made the mold just before interment. But the autopsy report (Evidence 16) is about the Professor's execution and death. If the body was interred, then Tusspells would have had access to the real corpse. However, the waxwork head (Evidence 15) was stolen. But the contradiction might be that the autopsy report states the Professor's death was confirmed, but the waxwork was made from the actual corpse, which would require the body to be present. However, if there's a rumor about resurrection (Evidence 19), maybe the body wasn't actually there, implying that the mold wasn't made from the real corpse. Wait, but Tusspells' testimony says she made the mold from the corpse, so if the autopsy report confirms death, then there's no contradiction. Hmm.

Wait, maybe another angle. Testimony 3 says Tusspells hid until she got a signal and was there a long time. Testimony 4 says it took a long time because before rigor mortis. Rigor mortis starts 2-6 hours after death. If the execution was at midnight, and she started working before rigor mortis, she would have to be there in the early hours. But the article (Evidence 19) talks about a resurrection on the night of execution, which was the same night. If the body was buried but then someone dug it up, but Tusspells made the mold before interment. Wait, the timeline might be conflicting. Let me check the testimonies again.

Testimony 2: Created the mold in the cemetery just before interment. Testimony 3: Hiding until a signal, long time. Testimony 4: Took long because before rigor mortis. Testimony 5: Worried about being discovered as dawn approached. Testimony 6: Finished in half hour before sunrise and left when corpse was interred.

So she was working on the body all night, finishing before sunrise. The execution was at midnight. So the body was buried (interred) in the early morning. But the autopsy report (Evidence 16) states that death was confirmed at midnight. So if the body was interred the next morning, how does that tie in? Maybe the contradiction is that the autopsy report lists the death as confirmed by Courtney Stevens (maybe a typo, since the coroner is Courtney Sithe, Character 13). Wait, in Evidence 16, the autopsy report is signed by Courtney Stevens. But the character is Courtney Sithe. That's a discrepancy. But the user might have a typo there. Alternatively, perhaps the real name is Stevens, but in the characters, it's Sithe. That could be a contradiction. But how does that relate to the testimonies?

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 15 (Waxwork Head) and Testimony 2. Tusspells says she made the mold from the corpse, but the Waxwork Head was stolen from the exhibit. If the mold was made from the actual corpse, the waxwork would be accurate. However, if the autopsy report (Evidence 16) says the Professor was executed, but the waxwork's head exists, maybe implying the corpse's appearance was captured, but the autopsy report's details conflict with that. Wait, maybe the contradiction is that the autopsy report says the Professor was hanged, but the waxwork's head (made from the corpse) would show signs of hanging, but in the waxwork, maybe it doesn't? But how is that evidenced?

Alternatively, consider Evidence 19: the ten-year-old article about the resurrection rumor. If Tusspells made the waxwork based on the corpse, but the article suggests the Professor came back to life, which would be impossible if he was confirmed dead. But Tusspells' testimony supports that the corpse was real, while the article's rumor suggests he wasn't dead, creating a contradiction. But that's between the article and the testimony, not the autopsy report.

Wait, let's check the Killer's Autopsy Report (Evidence 16). It says death by hanging confirmed at midnight, 17th June, signed by Courtney Stevens. The testimony from Tusspells (Testimony 2, 3, 4, 6) indicates that she was present at the burial site, making the mold before interment, which would be after the execution. If the body was indeed buried, then the waxwork is accurate. But the article (Evidence 19) talks about a resurrection rumor, implying the body was not in the grave. So if Tusspells made the mold from the corpse before interment, but then the body was stolen, leading to the resurrection rumor, there's no direct contradiction. However, the problem is between a testimony and evidence.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 2 (Tusspells made the mold just before interment) and Evidence 16 (the autopsy report). If the autopsy report confirms death, and Tusspells made the mold from the actual corpse, then there's no contradiction. But if the autopsy report is falsified, then maybe. Alternatively, the timing: the execution was at midnight, and the interment would be the next day. Tusspells was working on the body during the night, finishing before sunrise. So the interment happened in the morning. But the article (Evidence 19) talks about the resurrection on the night of execution, which would be the same night as the execution. So if the body was interred the next morning, how could it be stolen the same night? That might be a contradiction between the article (resurrection on execution night) and Tusspells' testimony (she was there until morning). But the question asks for evidence and testimony. So maybe Evidence 19 (the article about resurrection on the night of execution) contradicts Testimony 6 (she left when the corpse was interred at dawn). Because if the body was interred at dawn, how could it be stolen the same night (execution night)? The resurrection rumor happened the same night as the execution, but the interment was at dawn, which is the next day. So the article's timeline of the resurrection on the night of the 17th (execution date) would conflict with Tusspells' testimony that she interred the body at dawn (which would be the 18th). Therefore, the body couldn't have been stolen on the night of the 17th if it was interred on the 18th. Hence, the article (Evidence 19) contradicts Testimony 6.

But the user wants only one pair. Let me confirm. The testimonies are from Tusspells. Evidence 19 is the article about the resurrection on the night of execution. Testimony 6 says she left after interment at dawn. So if the resurrection rumor is that the body was stolen the same night as the execution (17th), but Tusspells was there until dawn (18th), then the article's claim of the resurrection on the 17th is impossible because the body wasn't buried until the 18th. Therefore, Evidence 19 contradicts Testimony 6.

Alternatively, another angle: Testimony 2 says Tusspells made the mold in the cemetery just before interment. But Evidence 16 (autopsy report) says the death was confirmed by Courtney Stevens (Sithe?), and if the body was in the cemetery for the mold, that's consistent. However, the waxwork head (Evidence 15) was stolen, but that's not directly contradictory.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 16. The autopsy report says the Professor was executed and confirmed dead, but Tusspells' Testimony 2 says she made the mold from the corpse before interment. If the autopsy report is accurate, then the body was properly handled, and Tusspells could have made the mold. But if the body was confirmed dead and buried, but the waxwork's head was stolen (Evidence 15), perhaps implying someone wanted to hide the true appearance. But I'm not sure.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 12: Camera from the waxwork, which is Drebber's camera from ten years ago with dark staining. Testimony 3 says Tusspells hid until a signal. If Drebber was involved in grave robbing, maybe he took a photo, but the camera's presence in the waxwork exhibit suggests Tusspells had it. But not directly related to testimonies.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says Tusspells hid until she got a signal and was there a long time. But Evidence 18 is Drebber's contract with Asman. Not related.

Wait, another angle: The autopsy report (Evidence 16) lists the coroner as Courtney Stevens, but the character's name is Courtney Sithe (Character 13). That's a contradiction. But the user may have a typo here. If the report is signed by Stevens, but the actual coroner is Sithe, that's a discrepancy. However, the testimony from Tusspells doesn't mention the coroner's name, so this might not be the contradiction we're looking for.

Back to the initial thought: Evidence 19 (article about resurrection on the night of execution) and Testimony 6 (Tusspells left at dawn after interment). If the article claims the resurrection happened on the night of the 17th (execution date), but the body wasn't interred until dawn (18th), then the body couldn't have been stolen on the 17th. Hence, the article's claim is contradicted by Tusspells' testimony. So the pair would be Evidence 19 and Testimony 6.

But the user wants the answer in JSON like {"evidence": 19, "testimony": 6}.

Alternatively, another possible contradiction: Testimony 2 says she made the mold in the cemetery just before interment, but Evidence 15 (Waxwork Head) is stolen. If the mold was made from the real corpse, the waxwork should be accurate, but perhaps the stolen head implies someone wanted to hide the true appearance. Not sure.

Alternatively, the crossbow (Evidence 3) belongs to Drebber, but Tusspells' testimonies don't mention him. Not related.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 16. Testimony 2 says she made the mold from the corpse, but the autopsy report (Evidence 16) says the death was confirmed. If the autopsy report is accurate, then the body was dead, so making a mold from it is possible. No contradiction there.

Alternatively, the Piece of Green Cloth (Evidence 4) has scorch marks. Not related.

Hmm. The most plausible contradiction seems to be between the article (Evidence 19) and Testimony 6. Because the article claims the resurrection happened on the night of the execution, but according to Tusspells, the body wasn't interred until dawn, so the resurrection couldn't have happened the same night. Therefore, the article's claim is contradicted by Tusspells' testimony about the timing.

Person: Drebber

Person: Drebber
Testimony 2

Testimony 4
Testimony: There was no gunshot from behind me at all. Nor any splattering blood.

Testimony 5
Testimony: Soon afterwards, I was visited by a young woman who sculpted a model of me from wax.

Testimony 6

cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. So, the user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and I need to find one pair where the evidence and testimony don't match up.

First, let me go through the testimonies. All the testimonies are from Drebber (Character 14). Let's look at each one:

Testimony 0: He was in Lowgate Cemetery for moonlighting (probably graverobbing). Testimony 1: The newspaper article's illustration was based on what he saw. Testimony 2: He didn't actually see the Professor. Testimony 3: He saw another graverobber. Testimony 4: No gunshot or blood. Testimony 5: A woman made a wax model of him. Testimony 6: He gave up science because of the article.

Now, looking at the evidence. Let's check each evidence related to Drebber or the events he's talking about.

Evidence 12 is the camera from the waxwork exhibit. The description says it's the actual camera Drebber had when he went graverobbing ten years ago. The lens has dark staining on the bellows. 

Testimony 5 says Drebber was visited by a woman who sculpted a wax model of him. That woman is probably Esmeralda Tusspells (Character 10), who runs the wax museum. The camera was part of the exhibit, and since Drebber was there graverobbing, the camera's presence there makes sense.

Wait, but how does this contradict any testimony? Let me think. Testimony 5 says he gave his likeness to the sculptor, which would explain the wax model. But Evidence 12 is the camera he had during the graverobbing. Maybe there's something here. Wait, the article (Evidence 19) is a ten-year-old article about the Professor's resurrection, which Drebber's testimony 1 refers to. The article's illustration was based on Drebber's account. But in Testimony 2, he says he never saw the Professor, only another graverobber. prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded. 
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago. [info] Condemned Prisoner 
 ***** (Redacted for confidentiality) 
 Pseudonym: The Professor 
 Ddeath by hanging confirmed at midnight, 17th June. 
 Courtney Stevens. 
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion. [caption] There is blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen. 
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It all began at the scene when I saw the waxwork and the note tucked inside its jacket.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 1
Testimony: The actual body of the victim, as indicated in the note's instructions, was beneath the experimentation stage.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The body had to be 'arranged' in certain ways to implicate the defendant...which was my job.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 3
Testimony: The actual cause of death was the neck trauma Asman suffered from the thirty-foot fall.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 4
Testimony: I stood over the victim's corpse where it lay in the toppled cage and plunged the screwdriver into the chest.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 5
Testimony: I enlisted the help of the entire Forensic Investigation Team to dress the scene appropriately.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 6
Testimony: The truth about the execution ten years ago is a state secret of the highest level. I had to protect it.
Person: Sithe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem. So, the task is to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants only one pair, and the answer must be in JSON at the end. Let me start by going through the provided materials step by step.

First, I need to look at all the testimonies given by Courtney Sithe. There are six testimonies here. Let's list them out:

Testimony 0: It all began at the scene when I saw the waxwork and the note tucked inside its jacket.
Testimony 1: The actual body of the victim, as indicated in the note's instructions, was beneath the experimentation stage.
Testimony 2: The body had to be 'arranged' in certain ways to implicate the defendant...which was my job.
Testimony 3: The actual cause of death was the neck trauma Asman suffered from the thirty-foot fall.
Testimony 4: I stood over the victim's corpse where it lay in the toppled cage and plunged the screwdriver into the chest.
Testimony 5: I enlisted the help of the entire Forensic Investigation Team to dress the scene appropriately.
Testimony 6: The truth about the execution ten years ago is a state secret of the highest level. I had to protect it.

Now, the evidences. There are 20 evidences listed (0-19). Let me skim through them to see which ones might relate to the testimonies. 

Looking at Testimony 3, Sithe says the cause of death was neck trauma from a 30-foot fall. Let's check the Autopsy Report (Evidence 6). The Autopsy Report states the victim's neck was broken from a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest. So according to the report, there are two injuries: neck trauma and a stab wound. But Testimony 3 says the actual cause of death was the neck trauma. However, in many cases, the cause of death is the fatal injury. If the neck trauma was the cause, then the stab wound would be post-mortem. But the autopsy report lists both. Wait, but according to Testimony 4, Sithe admits to plunging the screwdriver into the chest. That would mean the stab wound was inflicted after death. But the Autopsy Report (Evidence 6) says both injuries are present. If the cause of death is the neck trauma, then the stab wound was added later. So the autopsy report supports that the neck trauma was the cause. So maybe that's not a contradiction. Wait, but how does the Autopsy Report present the two injuries? Let me check again. The Autopsy Report (Evidence 6): "His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object." So it lists both injuries but doesn't specify which was the actual cause of death. However, Testimony 3 says the actual cause was the neck trauma, which would align with the autopsy report. So that seems consistent. Hmm. Maybe not the contradiction here.

Looking at Testimony 4: Sithe says she plunged the screwdriver into the chest. The screwdriver (Evidence 7) is described as having traces of blood at the tip, matching the victim's wound. But if the victim was already dead from the neck trauma, then the blood on the screwdriver would be from a post-mortem wound. However, blood doesn't flow after death, so if the screwdriver was inserted post-mortem, there might be little to no blood. But the presence of blood could indicate that the wound was inflicted ante-mortem. Wait, this is a possible contradiction. If the screwdriver was used after death (as per Testimony 4), then the blood on the screwdriver would be minimal or not flowing, but the evidence says there are traces of blood. So that might be a contradiction. Because if the victim was already dead from the fall, stabbing him wouldn't result in much blood on the screwdriver. Therefore, the presence of blood on the screwdriver (Evidence 7) suggests that the stab wound was inflicted while the victim was still alive, which contradicts Testimony 3 and 4. Wait, Testimony 3 says cause of death is neck trauma (so the fall killed him), and Testimony 4 says she added the stab wound post-mortem. But the screwdriver (Evidence 7) has blood traces. If the stab was post-mortem, there shouldn't be much blood, but the evidence says there are traces. That could be a contradiction. Therefore, Evidence 7 (Screwdriver) and Testimony 4 (where she admits to stabbing the corpse) would contradict each other because the blood on the screwdriver suggests the victim was alive when stabbed. But how does that work? Let me think again. If the victim died from the fall (neck broken), then the heart would stop, so when the screwdriver was inserted into the chest, there would be no active bleeding. However, some blood might still be present in the tissues, so maybe a small amount. The evidence says "traces" which might be possible. So maybe this isn't a solid contradiction. Alternatively, the autopsy report (Evidence 6) states the victim was stabbed. If the stab was post-mortem, the autopsy should note that the wound was post-mortem, but the report just says he was stabbed. However, the autopsy report may not specify the timing. So maybe this isn't a contradiction. Let me check another angle.

Looking at Testimony 4: She plunged the screwdriver into the chest. The screwdriver (Evidence 7) was found poking through the grille in the base of the machine. So the screwdriver was part of the machine's remains. But if she placed it there after the explosion, perhaps. But the blood on the screwdriver would be from the victim. If the victim was already dead from the fall, then the stab wouldn't produce active bleeding, so the blood on the screwdriver might be minimal. However, if the screwdriver was already in the machine, maybe the blood came from another source. Alternatively, perhaps the screwdriver was used to cause the explosion. Hmm, maybe not. Let me check another testimony and evidence pair.

Testimony 3 says the cause of death is neck trauma from the fall. Let's see Evidence 5: Photograph of the Victim shows an apparent stab wound. But according to Testimony 3 and 4, the stab was post-mortem. However, the photograph (if taken after the body was found) would show the stab wound. But that doesn't necessarily contradict unless the photo's caption says something conflicting. Let's check Evidence 5: "shows an apparent stab wound to the chest." The autopsy report also mentions the stab. So maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Looking at Testimony 3: Cause of death is neck trauma from the fall. But Evidence 17: Post-Explosion Photograph shows "blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen." If the victim's chest was stabbed post-mortem, then the blood from the chest wound wouldn't drip, since circulation has stopped. The presence of dripping blood suggests that the chest wound was inflicted before death. Therefore, this would contradict Testimony 3 and 4. So Evidence 17's caption mentions blood dripping from the chest, which implies the wound was inflicted while the heart was still pumping, i.e., before death. But according to Testimony 3 and 4, the cause of death was the neck trauma from the fall, and the chest wound was inflicted post-mortem. Therefore, the blood dripping in the photo (Evidence 17) would contradict Testimony 3's assertion that the neck trauma was the cause of death. Because if the chest wound caused bleeding while the heart was still beating, that could be the actual cause of death. Alternatively, the autopsy report (Evidence 6) says both injuries: neck broken and stab. So perhaps the cause of death is the combination, but Testimony 3 states that the actual cause is the neck trauma. If the blood dripping in the photo is from the chest wound and is significant, that suggests the victim was alive when stabbed. Therefore, the contradiction would be between Evidence 17 (Post-Explosion Photograph) and Testimony 3 (cause of death is neck trauma). Because the photo suggests the chest wound was inflicted ante-mortem, hence the dripping blood. Thus, if the chest wound was inflicted before death, then the cause of death could be the stab wound, contradicting Testimony 3. Therefore, the evidence (17) and testimony (3) contradict each other. Let me confirm. The photo's caption says "blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen." If the victim was stabbed post-mortem, the blood wouldn't drip in that manner. The blood would pool or coagulate, but not drip. So the presence of dripping blood implies that the wound was inflicted while the heart was still pumping, meaning before death. Therefore, if the cause of death was the neck trauma (from the fall), then the chest wound would have been after death, which contradicts the photo's evidence of active bleeding. Therefore, Evidence 17 contradicts Testimony 3. That seems like a solid contradiction.
